slides.title: Validation Classes
slides.ocrText: Validation Classes

slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

• Describe class-based validation

Identify which objects should use validation
classes

Explain how validation levels are used
Invoke class-based validation from different
locations in PolicyCenter

Write validation checks needed to validate
objects on a policy

slides.title: i Class-based validation
slides.originalNotes:
Class-based validation
When you need to run more complex validation against data in a policy transaction, you use the class-based validation. For example, before a policy is quoted, check all the coverages, drivers, vehicles, and other data are valid on a personal auto policy based on the business requirement.
slides.notes:
Class-based validation
When you need to run more complex validation against data in a policy transaction, you use the class-based validation. For example, before a policy is quoted, check all the coverages, drivers, vehicles, and other data are valid on a personal auto policy based on the business requirement.
slides.ocrText:
i Class-based validation

• Is validation used on-demand

« Allows users to:
* choose at what time to validate a data object
* decide how to validate data objects
* write complex validation logic in Gosu classes

slides.title: i What can be validated using class-based validation? [5
slides.originalNotes:
What can be validated using class- based validation?
PolicyCenter can perform class-based validation on basically any business object on a policy graph (including those objects that you create by extending a base object). You are quite free to write your own Gosu validation classes and implement your own validation logic.

There is nothing particularly special about these entities, meaning that they are not "validatable" entities in the sense that rule-based validation entities are defined as validatable- Guidewire merely provides validation classes for these entities in the base configuration. You are quite free to write your own Gosu validation classes and implement your own validation logic. A validation class can perform any number of checks against any policy-related entities in the system. In other words, everything in the policy graph is validatable-
slides.notes:
What can be validated using class- based validation?
PolicyCenter can perform class-based validation on basically any business object on a policy graph (including those objects that you create by extending a base object). You are quite free to write your own Gosu validation classes and implement your own validation logic.

There is nothing particularly special about these entities, meaning that they are not "validatable" entities in the sense that rule-based validation entities are defined as validatable- Guidewire merely provides validation classes for these entities in the base configuration. You are quite free to write your own Gosu validation classes and implement your own validation logic. A validation class can perform any number of checks against any policy-related entities in the system. In other words, everything in the policy graph is validatable-
slides.ocrText:
i What can be validated using class-based validation? [5

* Class-based validation may be performed on policy-related objects only such as:
* PolicyContactRole
* PolicyLocation
* PolicyPeriod
+ Line of business entities such as PALine or BALine
• Policy-specific entities such as PersonalVehicle or BusinessVehicle
• Everything on the policy graph can be validated using class-based validation
• Entities on a policy graph need not be defined specially or as validatable

* Validation class can perform any number of checks against any entities on a policy graph

slides.title: i PolicyCenter validation classes
slides.originalNotes:
PolicyCenter validation classes
Each validation class is either for validating a specific policy graph entity such as a Business Auto line of business or a business vehicle as shown in the example. Or it could be when you want to validate all the objects on a page in a jobwizard step such as validating all objects on the policy info page in a BOP submission wizard or on a Worker Compensation submission as shown in the screenshot.

slides.title: Validation levels
slides.ocrText: Validation levels

slides.title: Validation levels
slides.originalNotes:
Validation levels
In the base configuration, PolicyCenter defines a set of validation levels (in typelist Validation Level) that you can use to verify how valid data is before continuing. PolicyCenter uses the "priority" attribute of the type keys to order the validation levels.

PolicyCenter provides a list of validation levels — load save, default, quotable, bindable, quick quotable, and ready for issue in the ValidationLevel.ttx typelist extension in the base configuration. It is possible to modify, remove, or even add to them using the Studio type list editor.
slides.notes:
Validation levels
In the base configuration, PolicyCenter defines a set of validation levels (in typelist Validation Level) that you can use to verify how valid data is before continuing. PolicyCenter uses the "priority" attribute of the type keys to order the validation levels.

PolicyCenter provides a list of validation levels — load save, default, quotable, bindable, quick quotable, and ready for issue in the ValidationLevel.ttx typelist extension in the base configuration. It is possible to modify, remove, or even add to them using the Studio type list editor.

slides.title: Validation level priority
slides.originalNotes:
Validation level priority
In the base configuration "bindable" with a priority of 6000 is more restrictive than "quotable" with a priority of 7000- You can also think of this as tighter and looser (smaller numbers are tighter) to indicate more or less restrictive validation levels-
slides.notes:
Validation level priority
In the base configuration "bindable" with a priority of 6000 is more restrictive than "quotable" with a priority of 7000- You can also think of this as tighter and looser (smaller numbers are tighter) to indicate more or less restrictive validation levels-
slides.ocrText:
| Validation level priority G

The higher the priority value, the less restrictive the validation at that level is

ff) ValidationLevel.ttx. x

High

Restriction

Less

slides.title: i Validation levels and class-based validation
slides.originalNotes:
Validation levels and class-based validation
PolicyCenter provides methods in the PCValidationBase class to validate the entities in the base configuration

Unlike ClaimCenter an entity does not have a validation level associated with it. In PolicyCenter if the entity is validated at default level the next requirement may be to validate it at the quotable level or bindable level and then again at the default level. It is dependent upon how and when user wants to validate the entity.
slides.notes:
Validation levels and class-based validation
PolicyCenter provides methods in the PCValidationBase class to validate the entities in the base configuration

Unlike ClaimCenter an entity does not have a validation level associated with it. In PolicyCenter if the entity is validated at default level the next requirement may be to validate it at the quotable level or bindable level and then again at the default level. It is dependent upon how and when user wants to validate the entity.
slides.ocrText:
i Validation levels and class-based validation

• Run validation at a certain level on an entity or a wizard step
• See if all the validation checks required at the level are passed
« Add errors or warnings as needed for checks not passed

* PolicyCenter provides methods to determine what validation level is currently
being tested

questionData.question: Name three policy-related objects in PolicyCenter on which class-based validation is performed.
questionData.answer: Class-based validation can be performed on PolicyContactRole, PolicyLocation, PolicyPeriod, or any LOB entities, or any other policy-specific entities.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer G
Name three policy-related objects in PolicyCenter on which class-based
oo validation is performed.
Class-based validation can be performed on PolicyContactRole, PolicyLocation,
PolicyPeriod, or any LOB entities, or any other policy-specific entities.
SS Se ee eee eo

slides.title: —— Validation class implementations
slides.originalNotes:
Validation class implementations and methods
As a configuration developer, I want to describe validation class implementations and methods so that I can configure class based validation, such as adding validation checks, invoking class based validation and using validation chaining.
slides.notes:
Validation class implementations and methods
As a configuration developer, I want to describe validation class implementations and methods so that I can configure class based validation, such as adding validation checks, invoking class based validation and using validation chaining.
slides.ocrText:
—— Validation class implementations
and methods

slides.title: i Validation-related interfaces and classes
slides.originalNotes:
Validation-related interfaces and classes
The PCValidationBase is an abstract class that implements PCValidation.
The PolicyLineValidation class extends from abstract PC Validation base class- All the classes in the base configuration such as PALineValidatiom BOPValidation etc- are all subclasses of PolicyLineValidation class. All of these classes are discussed in detail in the following slides.

Note. In Object Oriented Programming, an interface generally defines the set of methods. The classes implement the interface must define the concrete logic for every method in the interface.
slides.notes:
Validation-related interfaces and classes
The PCValidationBase is an abstract class that implements PCValidation.
The PolicyLineValidation class extends from abstract PC Validation base class- All the classes in the base configuration such as PALineValidatiom BOPValidation etc- are all subclasses of PolicyLineValidation class. All of these classes are discussed in detail in the following slides.

Note. In Object Oriented Programming, an interface generally defines the set of methods. The classes implement the interface must define the concrete logic for every method in the interface.
slides.ocrText:
i Validation-related interfaces and classes Gi

PolicyCenter provides the following in the package gw. validation:
« PCValidation: Interface that all validation classes must implement
+ PCValidationBase: Abstract convenience class that takes a PCValidationContext instance

« PCValidationContext: Class that takes a ValidationLevel and creates a new
PCValidationResult object during initialization

« PCValidationResult: Class that contains the methods to use in generating warnings and
errors

slides.title: i PCValidation implementations
slides.originalNotes:
PCVaIidation implementations
The PCValidationBase exposes an abstract method validatelmpl hat subclasses can implement- PolicyLineValidation extends PCValidationBase and contains default logic that is not changeable by subclasses and hence finalizes validatelmpl and ha another overridable method called doValidate for its subclasses.

There are a few validation classes for some basic entities in the base product for example,
BOPBuildingValidation extends
AbstractBuildingValidatio n- The building validationclasses are called from the line-specific validation classes, e.g.BOPLineValidation calls BOPBuildingValidation.
Any Gosu class (or any interface defined in Gosu) that implements PCValidation can perform validation logic.
The first method in any validation class is the doValidate or the validatelmpl() method- It directs the flow of logic in a class- It simply calls other methods and each one of these methods checks for a single problem- The doValidate or the validatelmpl method performs no checks itself.
slides.notes:
PCVaIidation implementations
The PCValidationBase exposes an abstract method validatelmpl hat subclasses can implement- PolicyLineValidation extends PCValidationBase and contains default logic that is not changeable by subclasses and hence finalizes validatelmpl and ha another overridable method called doValidate for its subclasses.

There are a few validation classes for some basic entities in the base product for example,
BOPBuildingValidation extends
AbstractBuildingValidatio n- The building validationclasses are called from the line-specific validation classes, e.g.BOPLineValidation calls BOPBuildingValidation.
Any Gosu class (or any interface defined in Gosu) that implements PCValidation can perform validation logic.
The first method in any validation class is the doValidate or the validatelmpl() method- It directs the flow of logic in a class- It simply calls other methods and each one of these methods checks for a single problem- The doValidate or the validatelmpl method performs no checks itself.
slides.ocrText:
i PCValidation implementations Gi

* All validation classes must implement PCValidation or extend its implementation
classes

• Entity validation classes extend PCValidationBase
+ Such as PersonalVehicleValidation or BOPBuildingValidation classes
* The subclasses have a validatelmpl() method

* Policy Line validation classes extend PolicyLineValidation
* such as PALineValidation or BOPLineValidation classes
+ The subclasses have a doValidate() method

* Each validation class has a validatelmpl or a doValidate method

* calls other validation methods that check a single problem

slides.title: i Define validation methods that test for a single issue [5
slides.originalNotes:
Define validation methods that test for a single issue
For example, the PALineValidation calls the
VehiclesValidator-doVali date which is defined in the
PALineVehiclesValidator class. The
PALineValidation class also defines
PALineVehiclesValidator as Vehicles Validator and is used in the call statement The
PALineVehiclesValidator defines and calls methods such as atLeastOneVehicle and all Garagesl nSame State, all of which have a very narrowly focused purpose.
Classes that extend the PC Validation Base or Policy Line Validation class can create methods that test for a single issue to validate data objects and call those methods from their implementation of the do Validate orvalidate lmpl method.

In general, the XXX Validation classes extend the PC Validation Base classe xtend the PC Validation Base class and validate a single entity, e.g., the Personal Vehicle Validation class- The XXX Validator classes extend the Policy Line Validation class and validate a component on the line, for example, the PALine Vehicles Validator for the entire list of vehicles on the Personal Auto Line.

slides.title: PcValidationContext
slides.originalNotes:
PCVaIidationContext
The PCValidationContext class provides several important methods used in managing validation. This class gathers contextual information for validation, including the validation level, results for accumulating errors and warnings, and a record of the classes and validation methods that have beenvisited. Use this method to create a PCValidation Result object to add errors or warnings after validation is performed
slides.notes:
PCVaIidationContext
The PCValidationContext class provides several important methods used in managing validation. This class gathers contextual information for validation, including the validation level, results for accumulating errors and warnings, and a record of the classes and validation methods that have beenvisited. Use this method to create a PCValidation Result object to add errors or warnings after validation is performed
slides.ocrText:
| PcValidationContext G

•« PCValidationBase constructor defines validation context PCValidationContext
•« PCValidationContext:

* Takes a ValidationLevel at which to perform validation

* Creates a new PCValidationResult to store validation results (errors and warnings)

© PALineVehiclesValidator.gs

slides.title: PcValidationContext methods
slides.originalNotes:
PCVaIidationContext methods
This class has several important methods for use in managing validation. This slide describes some of them briefly

Is At Least: This method is simply a test used to determine if validation should be checked. The is At Least method uses the validation levels priority - i.e., if valLeve/ is set to quotable then this method would only return true if the validation level specified in Validation Context was quotable, bindable or ready Forlssue. Using this method, you could also check for the validation level in the Context being equal to a specific validation level.
Add To Visited- This method provides the opportunity to trace validation logic, but it does not do so automatically To be effective, each method needs to make this call and pass in a method Name that matches its name. Every method invoked should call this method validation is the instance of the validation class to track and method Name is the method that is being invoked.
Has Visited- class Name is the fully qualified validation class name, including package and methodName is the method being invoked.

Show Visited- The string list of validation methods visited, which is produced by this method, is useful for debugging.
For more details on each method please refer to the Gosu Reference Guide.
slides.notes:
PCVaIidationContext methods

Is At Least: This method is simply a test used to determine if validation should be checked. The is At Least method uses the validation levels priority - i.e., if valLeve/ is set to quotable then this method would only return true if the validation level specified in Validation Context was quotable, bindable or ready Forlssue. Using this method, you could also check for the validation level in the Context being equal to a specific validation level.
Add To Visited- This method provides the opportunity to trace validation logic, but it does not do so automatically To be effective, each method needs to make this call and pass in a method Name that matches its name. Every method invoked should call this method validation is the instance of the validation class to track and method Name is the method that is being invoked.
Has Visited- class Name is the fully qualified validation class name, including package and methodName is the method being invoked.

Show Visited- The string list of validation methods visited, which is produced by this method, is useful for debugging.
For more details on each method please refer to the Gosu Reference Guide.
slides.ocrText:
| PcValidationContext methods

isAtLeast(valLevel)
Tests if the level specified by ValidationContext is at least atvalLevel
addToVisited(validation, methodName)
* Provides opportunity to trace validation logic

hasVisited(className, methodName)
* Indicates whether the combination of validation object and method have been seen before
* returns true if the combination has been visited before

showVisited()

• Produces a string that lists the validation methods that were visited as validation was
performed with the provided Context

slides.title: i PCValidationResult holds validation results
slides.originalNotes:
PCVaIidation ResuIt holds validation results
PCValidation Result holds the warnings and errors added by the validation implementation classes as problems discovered.
PCValidation Result contains a number of object methods that are mentioned in the slide that you can use in generating warnings and errors.
The arguments to the PC Validation Result methods are explained below:
object — the object you are validating
Val Level — validation level at which the error/warning should be added- For example, if the error/warning is added at the quotable level then it appears at quotable, bindable, and ready forissue levels.
Error Message warning Message — error message you want to be displaye when there is an error- Guidewire recommends using displaykeys for all string objects.
Wizard Stepld — (Optional) The id of the wizard step of the object- If you supply the wizard SteplD, the method creates a link to the wizard step with the ID wizard Stepld, if that is not the current step.

The add Field Error and add Field Warning have additional field strRelativeField Path which is a string relative to the path to the field –

PCValidation Results inherits several different forms of the reject method from the (platform) Validation Result class (which it subclasses).
slides.notes:
PCVaIidation ResuIt holds validation results
PCValidation Result holds the warnings and errors added by the validation implementation classes as problems discovered.

Wizard Stepld — (Optional) The id of the wizard step of the object- If you supply the wizard SteplD, the method creates a link to the wizard step with the ID wizard Stepld, if that is not the current step.

The add Field Error and add Field Warning have additional field strRelativeField Path which is a string relative to the path to the field –

PCValidation Results inherits several different forms of the reject method from the (platform) Validation Result class (which it subclasses).
slides.ocrText:
i PCValidationResult holds validation results Gi

• PCValidationResult is created by Context methods

* PCValidationResult class provides methods that hold the resulting warnings and
errors:

addError(object, valLevel, errorMessage, wizardStepld)
addFieldError(object, strRelativeFieldPath, valLevel, errorMessage, wizardStepld)
addWarning(object, valLevel, warningMessage, wizardStepld)

addFieldWarning(object, strRelativeFieldPath, valLevel, warningMessage, wizardStepld)

where: valLevel means that the error or warning will be added at that level or any level more
restrictive

slides.title: Validation chaining
slides.ocrText: Validation chaining

slides.title: i Validation chaining
slides.originalNotes:
Validation chaining
For example, if validating a Personal Auto line policy period, the code calls the Period Validate which then calls a class that validatesthe policy line. In turn, these classes chain to validations of entities they hold.
Note: Validation chaining is not automatic. For a class to perform validation chaining, you must specifically construct it to do so.
slides.notes:
Validation chaining
For example, if validating a Personal Auto line policy period, the code calls the Period Validate which then calls a class that validatesthe policy line. In turn, these classes chain to validations of entities they hold.
Note: Validation chaining is not automatic. For a class to perform validation chaining, you must specifically construct it to do so.
slides.ocrText:
i Validation chaining G

Validation chaining is the process of one validation class calling another validation
class to perform additional validation checks

Validate
Period
Validate
Line

Validate

Driver ,
Validate
Vehicle

[ER submission ovat) CoPeronatauto €fL08/28/2018 RayNewton Account #CO00143542 Underwire Applegate

slides.title: Validation chain flow
slides.originalNotes:
Validation chain flow
Objects on the PolicyPeriod are part of the policy-graph.
Initially, the PolicyPeriodValidation validate method executes a number of validation methods defined in PolicyPeriodValidation, each of which tests for a certain condition. Then for some validation other validation classes are called.
PolicyContactRoleVali dation performs validation on all contact roles on the policy period. The PolicyContactRoleValidation class gets called within a block to validate each contact role on the policy period

PolicyContactRoleFor SameContactValidatio n performs validation that runs on all PolicyContactRoles that share the same contact This also loops through all the shared contacts.

PolicyLocationValidati on gets called to validate each location- It also validates all territory codes on each PolicyLocation. Code executes a loop through all of the Location objects in PolicyLocations. For each Location, it calls the PolicyLocationValidation validate method on that object- The code that makes that call is in the PolicyLocationValidation class. For every PolicyLocation in the PolicyLocations array, an instance of the PolicyLocationValidation class is created using the Context object and the current location- Then, the validate() method for that instance is called- This executes validation logic against that particular
PolicyLocation. The method checkAnswers() in PolicyLocationValidation calls the AnswerValidation.doVa lidate() method, therefore it is another level of validation chaining.

The validateLine function calls the PolicyLineValidation class to validate individual lines on the policy The line validation classes may chain to other validation classes to validate specific entities and so on-
slides.notes:
Validation chain flow
Objects on the PolicyPeriod are part of the policy-graph.
Initially, the PolicyPeriodValidation validate method executes a number of validation methods defined in PolicyPeriodValidation, each of which tests for a certain condition. Then for some validation other validation classes are called.
PolicyContactRoleVali dation performs validation on all contact roles on the policy period. The PolicyContactRoleValidation class gets called within a block to validate each contact role on the policy period

PolicyContactRoleFor SameContactValidatio n performs validation that runs on all PolicyContactRoles that share the same contact This also loops through all the shared contacts.

PolicyLocationValidati on gets called to validate each location- It also validates all territory codes on each PolicyLocation. Code executes a loop through all of the Location objects in PolicyLocations. For each Location, it calls the PolicyLocationValidation validate method on that object- The code that makes that call is in the PolicyLocationValidation class. For every PolicyLocation in the PolicyLocations array, an instance of the PolicyLocationValidation class is created using the Context object and the current location- Then, the validate() method for that instance is called- This executes validation logic against that particular
PolicyLocation. The method checkAnswers() in PolicyLocationValidation calls the AnswerValidation.doVa lidate() method, therefore it is another level of validation chaining.

The validateLine function calls the PolicyLineValidation class to validate individual lines on the policy The line validation classes may chain to other validation classes to validate specific entities and so on-
slides.ocrText:
| Validation chain flow

3. Classes chain to
validations of entities

1. Call validate() 2. Invoke validate() method on

methods objects)

they hold

slides.title: i Invoking class-based validation
slides.originalNotes:
Invoking class-based validation
The PolicyCenter user interface framework handles rendering of all errors and warnings raised through exceptions automatically. In case of workflow steps, user can invoke validation.
slides.notes:
Invoking class-based validation
The PolicyCenter user interface framework handles rendering of all errors and warnings raised through exceptions automatically. In case of workflow steps, user can invoke validation.
slides.ocrText:
i Invoking class-based validation Gi

* Class-based validation must be explicitly invoked through:

* Code, job processes, wizard steps, workflow steps, integration plug-ins, or from any Gosu
code

• To invoke validation from a particular PolicyCenter location:
* Wizard steps - use beforeSave attribute for that step
• Pop-ups - use beforeCommit attribute for that pop-up

slides.title: Question

questionData.question:
Name the validation context method that produces a string of methods
that were visited as validation was performed.
questionData.answer:
The showVisited() method shows a list of methods as a string that were visited as
validation was performed.

slides.title: Question
slides.ocrText:
Question G
Define validation chaining.
•
•
SS oe ee oe oe oo

questionData.question: Define validation chaining.
questionData.answer:
Validation chaining is the process of one validation class calling another validation
class to perform additional validation checks.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer G
Define validation chaining.
•
•
Validation chaining is the process of one validation class calling another validation
class to perform additional validation checks.
SS Se ee eee eo

slides.title: Creating a new validation class
slides.ocrText:
Creating a new validation class
and adding a validation check

slides.title: i Creating a new validation class
slides.ocrText:
i Creating a new validation class

For new entities:
* Create new validation class for entity you want to validate or
* Create new validation class when you create a new LOB
For existing entities:
+ Ifa validation class for the entity exists add validation check methods to that class
• If the validation class does not exist, then create new validation class
New class should extend PCValidationBase

Use an existing validation class as a reference

slides.title: Adding a validation check
slides.ocrText:
| Adding a validation check

ak WN =

. Edit/add appropriate validation class

. Add the validation check method

. Call method from validatelmpl() or doValidate()
. Invoke the method

. Verify the result in the UI
